Problem:
Consider a system governed by the Schrödinger equation \\(i \\hbar \\frac{\\partial \\psi}{\\partial t} = H \\psi\\), where \\(H\\) is the Hamiltonian operator. We examine the effect of a unitary transformation \\(U(t) = e^{-i At}\\) on the wave function \\(\\psi\\), with \\(A\\) being a Hermitian operator.

If during the evolution, at time \\( t_1 \\), a new unitary function \\( V(t) = e^{-i Bt} \\) (where \\(B\\) is another Hermitian operator) is applied as an intervention, will the final state \\( \\psi(T) \\) for T > t_1 depend only on \\(H\\) and not on \\(A\\) or \\(B\\)?
Explanation: Introducing \\( V(t) \\) changes the evolution of the wave function substantially by adding another layer of unitary transformation. The resulting state at time T will depend not only on the original Hamiltonian \\(H\\) but also significantly on both \\(A\\) and \\(B\\). The contributions of \\(A\\) and \\(B\\) interplay through the combined effect of the unitary operations.
